证据片段: Thermal expansion coefficients are taken from recent work by MacEwen and Faber [23], who used neutron diffraction to determine residual thermal strains in Zircaloy-2 rod. In the basal plane, the thermal expansion is isotropic; $\alpha _ { 1 } = \alpha _ { 2 } = 5 . 7 \times 1 0 ^ { - 6 } \mathrm { K } ^ { - 1 }$ Normal to the basal plane $\alpha _ { 3 } = 1 1 . 4 \times 1 0 ^ { - 6 } \mathrm { K } ^ { - 1 }$

文献ID: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk7
证据片段: Many of the features of the deformation of Zircaloy-2, including the strength differential, the initial workhardening rates in tension and compression, and the Bauschinger effect are direct consequences of the residual stresses produced by anisotropic thermal expansion and plastic flow.

文献ID: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_047_chunk7
证据片段: The underprediction of the plastic strain required to reach the fully plastic state in all grains is a consequence of the Taylor assumption that the strain in each grain is the same as in the body as a whole.

证据片段: In rod-textured Zircaloy-2, deformed at room temperature in uniaxial tension or compression, we observe the following. In tension, for strains less than $4 \%$ , there are no twins at all.
